seed: I keep overthinking everything at work, and I'm scared I'm going to get fired even though nobody said anything.

transcript.content: I keep overthinking everything at work, and I'm scared I'm going to get fired even though nobody said anything.

It sounds like you're feeling quite anxious about your job, and it seems that you might be worrying excessively about potential issues that haven't been addressed yet. Have you noticed any specific events or situations that are causing this fear of getting fired? Let's try to explore these triggers together and see if we can find a more balanced perspective on the situation.
I just keep replaying conversations in my head, thinking maybe I said something wrong or wasn't good enough in meetings. It feels like I’m constantly waiting for the other shoe to drop.

It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of anxiety after meetings, and you might be ruminating on past interactions. This could be due to concerns about how well you performed or if there was something you could have done differently. Have you ever noticed that this pattern tends to happen more often with certain types of conversations or people? And when you're caught up in these thoughts, do you find it difficult to focus on other things?
Yeah, it definitely happens more when I’m with my boss or in big group settings. I feel like I can’t concentrate on anything else; it just eats at me.

It sounds like you're experiencing a significant amount of distress when you're around your boss or in large groups. This might be a sign that certain situations are triggering some automatic thoughts for you, such as feeling overwhelmed or unable to focus. Have you ever considered that these thoughts might not necessarily reflect the reality of the situation? For instance, could there be other factors at play that you're not aware of yet? Could we explore those together?
I just feel this tightness in my chest and everything feels so heavy when those situations come up. It's like my mind is racing, but my body just freezes in fear.

I understand that certain situations can make you feel quite overwhelmed, and it seems like your body responds with a sense of physical tension and a racing mind, while at the same time feeling frozen with fear. This might be a sign that your thoughts are racing faster than usual, which could potentially be linked to feelings of anxiety.

Could we explore together what specific thoughts might be causing this reaction in you? For instance, is there a particular thought or belief that tends to arise when you find yourself in these situations?
I guess I just keep thinking that everyone else is so much better at their jobs than I am, like I don’t belong there. It makes me feel like I’m just faking it, and any minute someone will find out.

I can see that you've been feeling quite insecure about your abilities at work, as if others are more competent than you. This thought seems to be causing a lot of shame and self-doubt, making you feel like you're not truly part of the team.

Have you ever considered that this might be an overgeneralization? It's possible that you're focusing on the few instances where you feel less confident, while ignoring all the times when you've done well. Could there be situations at work where you excel and contribute significantly?
I get what you’re saying, but when I’m caught up in those feelings, it’s like I can’t remember any of the good stuff. All I see are the times I messed up, and it just spirals from there.

It sounds like you're experiencing a pattern where you focus on your mistakes rather than the positive moments. This could be a sign of rumination, which is when we keep thinking about something over and over without finding a solution.

Have you ever noticed that this pattern tends to make you feel worse instead of helping you learn from your mistakes? It might be helpful to explore if there's a way to balance your thoughts so you can remember the good along with the bad. Could we take a closer look at how this thought pattern usually starts for you, and see if we can find any triggers or early signs that lead to this cycle?

I can definitely see that pattern, like I just get stuck on the negative and can’t let it go. It usually starts with a small comment or a mistake, and then my brain just takes off from there, like it’s on a runaway train.

I understand that you've been feeling stuck on the negative thoughts, and they often seem to start from a small comment or a minor mistake. It's as if your mind has a tendency to escalate things beyond their actual significance. Could we explore together why your brain might be doing this? For instance, is there a particular belief or assumption that you hold about yourself or the situation that could be contributing to this pattern?
I think deep down I’ve always felt like I have to be perfect to prove I’m worthy. If I mess up even a little, it feels like I’m confirming that I’m not good enough.

It sounds like you're carrying a heavy burden of self-expectation, almost as if you believe perfection is the only way to validate your worth. However, have you ever considered that everyone makes mistakes and it doesn't necessarily mean they're not worthy or capable? Can you think about a time when you made a mistake but still felt valuable afterwards?

I guess I can remember a time when I messed up a project at work, but my team stepped in and helped me fix it. It felt good to see that they cared, but I still couldn’t shake off that nagging feeling of embarrassment.

It sounds like you've been dealing with a persistent sense of embarrassment after making a mistake at work. Interestingly, it seems this feeling has persisted even though your team helped resolve the issue. Have you ever considered that perhaps your team's support might indicate their confidence in your abilities, rather than your own perceived shortcomings? Could there be other reasons why you feel embarrassed despite their assistance?
I know they were supportive, but it still feels like I let them down, you know? That embarrassment just keeps creeping back, like I’ll never really be good enough, no matter what they say.

It sounds like you're carrying a heavy burden of self-doubt, even though others have shown their support. Could we explore together why you might be thinking that you've let them down and why this thought seems to persist despite their reassurances? Perhaps there's an underlying belief or assumption that needs to be addressed?

It’s just this deep fear that if I mess up once, people will see me differently, like I’m not competent. I guess I’ve always held on to this idea that perfection is the only way to be valued, and when I slip up, it feels like I’m proving my own worst fears right.

cbt_context.patient_text: I keep overthinking everything at work, and I'm scared I'm going to get fired even though nobody said anything.
I just keep replaying conversations in my head, thinking maybe I said something wrong or wasn't good enough in meetings. It feels like I’m constantly waiting for the other shoe to drop.

behaviors: waiting for the other shoe to drop

concepts.term: Social phobia, fear of public speaking (disorder)

automatic_thoughts: I can’t concentrate on anything else

cbt_context.patient_text: I just feel this tightness in my chest and everything feels so heavy when those situations come up. It's like my mind is racing, but my body just freezes in fear.

concepts.term: Acute panic state due to acute stress reaction (disorder)
Anxiety disorder due to a general medical condition (disorder)
